content.description: Follow a shallow corner to a good ledge. A hard to read sequence through hard to see holds will get you through another corner system to jugs, or one can traverse to the right side of the ledge and make big moves to the same jugs. After clipping the last bolt from underclings, head up and left. This has great movement and great rock.
content.protection: Seven bolts to a two bolt anchor with chains and biners.
content.location: After passing the fixed rope, head around an arete and the route will be found in a corner. There is an offwidth crack to the left and a huge diving board looking rock directly overhead.

content.description:
This route is one of the most striking & aesthetic lines in the Poudre Canyon and is well worth a trip up to the EO.

Start in the short off-width crack, pull a small roof, boulder problem crux, and keep it together up the long headwall. Placing gear can be a bit tricky, especially through the crux, so be careful.
content.protection: Standard rack + bring extra thin gear and a #5 Camalot for the off-width. There is a two-bolt ring anchor at the top of the climb. TR work to suss the gear and moves is highly suggested...but getting to the top of the route is tricky.
content.location: This is one of the first climbs you come to after completing the hike.

content.description:
This is a sporty sport route that starts with a boulder problem followed by a slab that keeps your attention all the way to the anchors.

P1) 5.10b/c. Boulder up to a big ledge on the left, then follow bolts up a continuous slab possibly placing a cam at an overlap.
content.protection: Seven bolts and an optional one inch cam.
content.location:
This is the last route to the right of

Prometheus Rising

before getting to the fixed rope leading to the Seventh Wave.

content.description: The crux is at the 3rd bolt!!!
